questions.text: For Health Education, the Motivation Model has its 1st  Step as Awareness. Its 2nd  Step is Motivation. Its 3rd  Step is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Action

 

The Motivation Model for Health Education comprises three steps:

 

  1. Awareness: This step involves generating interest in the person’s mind about the health topic or problem.
  2. Motivation: This stage includes evaluation and decision-making, where the person is encouraged and motivated to consider the health information or behavior change.
  3. Action: This is the final step where the individual accepts and adopts the health idea or practice. The person moves from motivation to implementation, engaging in the recommended health behavior.

 

Other 2 Models are –

 

  • Medical Model – This involves interaction between the patient and doctor, where the patient presents their illness, and the doctor diagnoses it as a disease.
  • Social Interactive Model

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dedication: Dedication is not explicitly a step in the Motivation Model but can be an outcome of sustained action and commitment to the behavior change.

 

Option C. Contemplation: Contemplation is a stage in other health behavior change models, such as the Transtheoretical Model, where individuals consider changing but do not yet take action. It is not the third step in the Motivation Model.

 

Option D. Reflection: Reflection is not part of the Motivation Model’s steps. It typically refers to thinking back on actions and decisions, often occurring after the behavior has been implemented.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The third step in the Motivation Model for Health Education is Action, which signifies the adoption and implementation of the health behavior.

questions.text: A female patient with a BMI of 35 kg/m2 presents to you with a skin lesion in the axilla as shown below. Which of the following condition is she most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metabolic syndrome

 

  • The skin lesion shown in the image of axilla with velvety textured skin is indicative of Acanthosis nigricans. In this case, the patient is most likely suffering from Metabolic syndrome based on the diagnosis.

 

Acanthosis nigricans

  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism:

  • Hypothyroidism primarily manifests with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, bradycardia, alopecia and dry skin. It doesn't typically lead to velvety skin changes like Acanthosis nigricans.

 

Option C. Addison’s disease:

  • Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, leads to symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, salt craving, and hyperpigmentation. However, the hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's is more diffuse and not restricted to velvety changes in the axilla.

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism:

  • This condition primarily results from an overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to elevated calcium levels in the blood. Symptoms include kidney stones, bone pain, and fatigue. Skin changes like Acanthosis nigricans are not a typical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References –

Harrisons principle s of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 390, 2933,2934, 2936, 2970, 2971, 3086, 3150, 3151, 3154, 3155, 3156, 3173, 3175

Current Medical Diagnosis & Treatment 2022 Page no 1157

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 147, Page no 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 391

questions.text: Deoxygenated blood is returned to the placenta from the fetus through? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Umbilical artery

 

Explanation:

 

Fetal circulation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Umbilical vein: Carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, not deoxygenated blood.

 

Option C. Ductus arteriosus: Shunts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta in fetal circulation, bypassing the lungs. It does not return deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Ductus venosus: Shunts blood from the umbilical vein to the IVC, allowing oxygenated blood to bypass the liver. It does not return deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deoxygenated blood exits the fetus through the umbilical arteries, which return it to the placenta.

 

Ref: Page no 343, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with epithelial ovarian cancer has peritoneal metastases and ascites. What is the management? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Debulking followed by chemotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

For advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases and ascites, the preferred treatment is surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy. This approach helps reduce tumor load and enhances chemotherapy effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Debulking followed by radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not typically used as a first-line treatment in ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy followed by debulking: Starting with chemotherapy may be considered, but debulking first is usually preferred.

 

Option D. Staging laparotomy: Staging laparotomy is primarily diagnostic, not therapeutic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In advanced epithelial ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement, initial surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy is the standard management approach to maximize treatment efficacy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female, on treatment for diabetes for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of candidal vulvovaginitis in the last two months. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, a class of drugs used to treat type 2 diabetes. One of the well-known side effects of SGLT2 inhibitors is an increased risk of fungal infections, particularly candidal infections of the genital tract. This is because SGLT2 inhibitors increase the amount of glucose excreted in the urine, creating an environment conducive to fungal growth. Therefore, in patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, such as the 60-year-old female in this case, SGLT2 inhibitors like canagliflozin should be avoided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: The most common side effect of metformin is gastrointestinal upset, particularly diarrhea. It does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Option C. Glipizide: This sulfonylurea drug primarily causes hypoglycemia as a side effect. It does not have a significant association with increased risk of fungal infections.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: This drug can cause weight gain due to fluid retention but does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, SGLT2 inhibitors, such as canagliflozin, should be avoided due to their association with increased risk of genital fungal infections.

questions.text: The hormone acting on post ovulatory endometrium is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progesterone

 

Post ovulation, there is a significant rise in progesterone levels, which is crucial for the transformation of the endometrium into a secretory phase. This phase is essential for preparing the endometrium for potential implantation of an embryo.

 

Phases of the Menstrual Cycle:

 

  1. Menstruation (0 - 4 days):
    • The shedding of the endometrial lining occurs if there is no pregnancy.
  2. Follicular Phase (10 - 14 days):
    • Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.
    • Estrogen levels rise, leading to the proliferation of the endometrium.
  3. Ovulation (14th day):
    • Luteinizing hormone (LH) surge leads to the release of an ovum from the dominant follicle.
  4. Luteal Phase (14 - 28 days):
    • The corpus luteum forms and secretes progesterone.
    • Progesterone causes the endometrium to develop secretory glands and prepare for implantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luteinizing Hormone: LH is primarily involved in triggering ovulation and the formation of the corpus luteum.

 

Option B. Follicle-Stimulating Hormone: FSH is crucial for the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles during the follicular phase.

 

Option D. Estrogen: Estrogen is significant during the follicular phase for the proliferation of the endometrium but is not the main hormone acting on the post-ovulatory endometrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone is the hormone responsible for preparing the endometrium for implantation during the post-ovulatory phase.

 

Ref: Page no 94, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perinatal transmission 

 

The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is through perinatal transmission. Perinatal transmission, also known as vertical transmission, occurs during labor and delivery. This can happen when the newborn is exposed to infected blood and cervicovaginal secretions in the birth canal.

 

Mechanisms of HIV Transmission in Infants:

 

  • In utero (During pregnancy): HIV can cross the placenta from the mother to the fetus.
  • During delivery (Perinatal): This is the most common mode of transmission and occurs when the baby is exposed to infected blood and secretions during the birthing process.
  • After birth by breastfeeding: This is a less common mode of transmission compared to perinatal transmission but still significant, especially in regions where breastfeeding is essential for infant nutrition.

 

Risk Factors for Vertical Transmission:

 

  • High maternal viremia (most important)
  • Preterm delivery (<34 weeks)
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours)
  • Low birth weight
  • Low maternal CD4 count

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast milk: While breast milk can transmit HIV, it is less common compared to perinatal transmission during delivery.

 

Option C. Transplacental: HIV can be transmitted transplacentally during pregnancy, but this is not as common as perinatal transmission.

 

Option D. Exchange transfusion with infected blood: This is a rare cause of HIV infection in newborns compared to perinatal transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is perinatal transmission, occurring during labor and delivery.

questions.text: What blood group can be transfused to an individual with Bombay blood group? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oh

 

The Bombay blood group, also known as the Oh blood group, is a rare blood type that lacks the H antigen, which is present in all other blood types. Individuals with the Bombay blood group have antibodies against the H antigen, which means they cannot receive blood from any of the common ABO blood groups, including the universal donor O blood group, as it contains the H antigen. Transfusing blood that contains the H antigen to someone with the Bombay blood group would lead to a severe hemolytic reaction. Therefore, individuals with the Bombay blood group can only receive blood from other Bombay blood group donors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AB negative: This blood group contains the H antigen and would cause a hemolytic reaction in a Bombay blood group individual.

 

Option B. B: This blood group also contains the H antigen, making it incompatible with the Bombay blood group.

 

Option D. O negative: Although O negative is considered a universal donor in the context of the ABO and Rh systems, it still contains the H antigen and is therefore not compatible with the Bombay blood group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Individuals with the Bombay blood group (Oh) can only receive blood from other Bombay blood group donors due to the presence of anti-H antibodies.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for brachial plexus block. After some time, the patient developed hypotension and cardiovascular collapse. What is the best treatment for this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 20% Intralipid

 

In the case of hypotension and cardiovascular collapse following a bupivacaine brachial plexus block, the recommended treatment is intravenous lipid emulsion therapy (e.g., 20% Intralipid). This treatment is specifically targeted at reversing the toxic effects of bupivacaine, which is a lipophilic local anesthetic. The other options, while useful in various cardiovascular emergencies, are not the primary treatments for bupivacaine toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication used primarily for the treatment of certain types of serious arrhythmias. It's not typically used for the acute management of bupivacaine-induced cardiovascular collapse.

 

Option B. Epinephrine: This is a critical care drug used in the management of various life-threatening conditions, including anaphylaxis and cardiac arrest. It could be used in this scenario for its vasoconstrictive and positive inotropic effects, but it might not be the first choice due to the risk of exacerbating cardiac arrhythmias, which can be a complication of bupivacaine toxicity.

 

Option C. Dobutamine: This is a β1-selective vasoactive agent used primarily for the management of heart failure and cardiogenic shock. It increases cardiac output but would not be the first-line treatment for bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intralipid therapy is the recommended treatment for severe local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur with medications like bupivacaine. It acts by trapping lipophilic drugs like bupivacaine in an intravascular lipid emulsion, reducing their toxicity.

choices.text: It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments
It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA polymerase I? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is found in prokaryotes

 

This statement is correct. DNA polymerase I is primarily found in prokaryotic organisms, including bacteria. In prokaryotes, it plays a crucial role in DNA replication and repair.

 

Additional Information –

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg’s enzyme) from Escherichia coli (prokaryote). It is a repair  enzyme. It has both 3′ to 5′ and 5′ to 3′ exonuclease activities. When 5′ to 3′ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

DNA polymerases I, II, and III are prokaryotic polymerases.

 

DNA polymerase II: DNA proofreading and repair.

 

DNA polymerase III: Main replication enzyme in bacteria

 

In mammalian cells (eukaryotic), there are 5 DNA polymerases (DNAPs) named as α, β, γ, δ and ε.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments: DNA polymerase I main function is to remove RNA primers from Okazaki fragments and fill the gaps with DNA nucleotides. The synthesis of Okazaki fragments is primarily carried out by DNA polymerase III in prokaryotes.

 

Option C. It synthesizes RNA primers: DNA polymerase I does not synthesize RNA primers. Instead, it removes RNA primers by its 5' to 3' exonuclease activity as part of the primer removal process during DNA replication.

 

Option D. It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis: This statement is not true. While DNA polymerase I is involved in DNA replication, it is not the primary enzyme responsible for DNA synthesis. In prokaryotes, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme responsible for DNA synthesis during replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA polymerase I is a critical enzyme found in prokaryotes, involved in DNA replication and repair. While it plays key roles, including the removal of RNA primers from Okazaki fragments, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme for DNA synthesis in these organisms

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with tachypnea and mental confusion. His blood sugar is 350 mg/dL, pH - 7.2, HCO3- 10 mEq/L, pCO2 – 25 mmHg. What is the metabolic abnormality? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metabolic acidosis

 

The patient presents with a significantly acidic pH (7.2) and a low bicarbonate level (HCO3- = 10 mEq/L), indicating metabolic acidosis. The pCO2 is also reduced (25 mmHg), which suggests a respiratory compensatory mechanism aiming to increase acid excretion (by hyperventilating to blow off CO2) to counterbalance the acidosis.

 

This presentation is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a common complication of diabetes that leads to metabolic acidosis, elevated blood glucose, and electrolyte imbalances due to the production of ketoacids from the breakdown of fats. The high blood sugar level of 350 mg/dL supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis: Incorrect as the low HCO3- and acidic pH point to acidosis, not alkalosis.

 

Option C. Respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect as the low pCO2 is a compensatory response to the metabolic acidosis, not the primary disorder.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect as this would involve an elevated pCO2, opposite of what is observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the presence of high blood sugar and the reported ABG values, metabolic acidosis, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis, should be considered. This condition requires prompt recognition and management, typically involving fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy, and electrolyte management to reverse the ketosis and acidosis.

choices.text: Rest pain is seen more in the night
Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.
The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction

questions.text: Which of the statements regarding claudication pain is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.

 

Intermittent claudication is characterized by muscle pain (ache, cramp, numbness or sense of fatigue), classically in the calf muscle, which occurs during exercise and is relieved by a short period of rest (< 5 minutes). The pain does not typically start with the first step but develops after a predictable distance of walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rest pain is seen more in the night: True. Rest pain is a more severe symptom of peripheral artery disease (PAD). It typically indicates more advanced disease than intermittent claudication. This pain occurs when the limb is at rest, often at night due to the decreased perfusion that results from the horizontal position of the limb. It often awakens the patient from sleep and can be relieved by hanging the leg over the bed or walking.

 

Option C. Most common cause is atheroma: True. The most common cause of intermittent claudication is atherosclerosis (plaque or atheroma formation) in the peripheral arteries. This reduces blood flow to the muscles during activity, causing pain.

 

Option D. The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction: True. The site of pain (e.g., calf, thigh) does not always directly correlate with the level of arterial obstruction. For instance, while calf pain is often due to femoropopliteal disease, it can also be caused by aortoiliac disease. However, the location of claudication pain can provide a clue to the level of disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement among the provided options is that pain in intermittent claudication occurs at the first step of walking.

choices.text: HLA B27 is associated in 90% cases
It is non-erosive and only joints are affected
Involvement of sacroiliac joint is earliest sign
Affects males more than females

questions.text: All are true about Ankylosing spondylitis except:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is non-erosive and only joints are affected

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by erosive changes.  
  • AS is not completely non-erosive.
  • Over time, inflammation can lead to erosive changes, especially in the sacroiliac joints and the spine.
  • The inflammatory process in AS often leads to erosion of the vertebrae and the formation of syndesmophyte (bone spurs), which contribute to the fusion of spinal segments.
  • While AS primarily affects the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), it can also involve other structures.
  • Extra-articular manifestations can include enthesitis (inflammation of the sites where tendons and ligaments attach to bone), uveitis (eye inflammation), and in some cases, systemic symptoms like fatigue and anemia.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HLA-B27 is associated in 90% of cases: HLA-B27 is a genetic marker that is strongly associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Approximately 90% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis test positive for the HLA-B27 antigen. However, not all individuals with this antigen will develop the disease, and not all AS patients will test positive for HLA-B27. The exact role of HLA-B27 in the pathogenesis of AS is not fully understood, but it is considered a significant genetic risk factor. HLA-B27 positivity is used as part of the diagnostic process and can help in predicting the likelihood of AS in patients with symptoms.

 

Option C. Involvement of sacroiliac joint is earliest sign: Sacroiliac joint involvement is often one of the earliest signs of ankylosing spondylitis. The sacroiliac joints are typically among the first to be affected in AS. Early symptoms include lower back pain and stiffness that improves with activity and worsens with rest. X-rays or MRI of the sacroiliac joints can reveal characteristic changes associated with AS, such as sacroiliitis (inflammation of the sacroiliac joints) and eventually, structural changes such as joint fusion.

 

 

Option D. Affects males more than females: Ankylosing spondylitis is more common in males than females. Studies suggest that the male-to-female ratio for AS is approximately 2:1 to 3:1. The disease may present differently in women, sometimes leading to a delay in diagnosis. Women with AS might have a less pronounced spinal involvement and more peripheral joint symptoms compared to men.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is an erosive inflammatory condition in which axial skeleton particularly in the spine and sacroiliac joints and other organs are affected.

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress. Chest X ray reveals air bubbles in the left hemithorax. What is your best possible diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a condition where there is an opening in the diaphragm, allowing abdominal contents to move into the chest cavity. This can lead to compression of the lungs and associated respiratory distress. The presence of air bubbles in the left hemithorax on chest X-ray is a characteristic finding for CDH, as the abdominal organs such as the stomach and intestines herniate into the thoracic cavity, causing air-filled loops to appear in the hemithorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital sequestration of lung: Congenital pulmonary sequestration is a rare condition where a portion of lung tissue develops separately from the normal lung tissue and lacks a connection to the bronchial tree. It typically presents with a solid mass or cystic lesion rather than air bubbles. The presence of air bubbles in the left hemithorax on chest X-ray is not consistent with this condition.

 

Option C. Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM): CCAM is a developmental lung abnormality characterized by the formation of cysts or masses of abnormal lung tissue. While it can lead to respiratory distress in newborns, it usually presents as a cystic or solid mass rather than air bubbles in the chest X-ray.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the best possible diagnosis given the described findings of air bubbles in the left hemithorax and respiratory distress in the newborn.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of air bubbles in the left hemithorax on chest X-ray is a characteristic finding for CDH

questions.text: What is altered in thyroid profile throughout pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total T3 level

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, the thyroid profile undergoes several changes due to physiological adaptations. One significant change is the increase in total T3 and T4 levels. This occurs because of the elevated levels of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG), which increases the amount of bound thyroid hormones. Despite this increase, the levels of free T3 and free T4 remain relatively unchanged.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thyroid-binding globulin (TBG): The production of TBG increases during pregnancy due to elevated estrogen levels. This leads to higher levels of total T3 and total T4.
  • Free T3 and Free T4: Despite the increase in total hormone levels, the free (unbound) hormone levels remain relatively stable. This is why free T3 and free T4 are preferred for thyroid function testing during pregnancy.
  • TSH: The levels of TSH may decrease slightly in the first trimester due to the thyrotropic effects of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), but they generally stabilize in the second and third trimesters.
  • Iodine requirement: Pregnancy increases the body's requirement for iodine by about 50%, due to increased renal clearance and fetal iodine needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Free T3 level: This remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Free T4 level: This also remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option D. TSH level: While TSH levels can decrease slightly in the first trimester, they typically stabilize throughout the rest of the pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, total T3 and T4 levels increase due to elevated thyroid-binding globulin, while free T3 and T4 levels remain unchanged.

 

Ref: Page no 57, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: After how many seconds of chest compressions and bag and mask ventilation, should we start the adrenaline? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 60 seconds

 

Adrenaline is administered during neonatal resuscitation when the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute after 60 seconds of effective bag and mask ventilation, or if the heart rate remains below 60 despite adequate bag and mask ventilation for 30 seconds. The prompt administration of adrenaline is crucial for improving perfusion and achieving successful resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenaline should be administered when the heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute after 60 seconds of bag and mask ventilation.

questions.text: How will you collect samples for blood culture in a patient with suspected Infective Endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3 aerobic and 3 anaerobic

 

Explanation:

 

Infective endocarditis is diagnosed using Duke's criteria, which includes major and minor criteria. One of the major criteria involves positive blood cultures.

 

For accurate diagnosis, it is essential to collect multiple blood cultures to identify the causative organism reliably.

 

A blood culture set includes both aerobic and anaerobic samples.

 

According to Duke's criteria:

 

  • A minimum of two cultures should be drawn at least 12 hours apart.
  • Ideally, three or more cultures should be collected.
  • When collecting three or more cultures, each culture set includes both aerobic and anaerobic samples.

 

Therefore, for three culture sets, you would collect three aerobic and three anaerobic samples.

 

The rules for collection are:

 

  1. If two culture sets are collected, both should be drawn at least 12 hours apart and both should be positive.
  2. If three or more culture sets are collected, all three should be positive for the same organism.
  3. If more than three culture sets are collected, the majority should be positive for the same organism.
  4. The gap between the first and the last culture should be at least one hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected infective endocarditis, the recommended blood culture collection includes three aerobic and three anaerobic samples to ensure accurate diagnosis and identification of the causative organism

questions.text: A pregnant female in first trimester developed deep vein thrombosis. She requires anticoagulation. Which of the following will be the preferred drug in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Enoxaparin

 

Enoxaparin is the preferred drug for a pregnant female with DVT, particularly in the first trimester. Its safety profile and effectiveness in treating and preventing DVT make it suitable for use in pregnancy. The other options either have safety concerns during pregnancy or are not typically used for the treatment of DVT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clopidogrel: This is an antiplatelet drug, not typically used in the treatment of DVT, and its safety in pregnancy is not well-established.

 

Option B. Warfarin: Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist and is generally contraindicated in pregnancy, especially during the first trimester, due to the risk of teratogenic effects (warfarin embryopathy).

 

Option C. Betrixaban: This is an oral Factor Xa inhibitor. The safety of betrixaban in pregnancy has not been established, and it is generally not recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred choice for anticoagulation in pregnancy because they do not cross the placenta and thus have a lower risk of fetal harm. Enoxaparin is effective in the treatment and prevention of DVT and is considered safe for use in pregnancy.

questions.text: SA node release following in response to increasing blood pressure:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetylcholine

 

Explanation

 

When blood pressure increases, baroreceptors (pressure-sensitive receptors located in the carotid sinus and aortic arch) are activated. These receptors detect the rise in blood pressure and send signals to the cardiovascular center in the medulla oblongata, specifically to the cardio-inhibitory center (CIC). Activation of the CIC results in the stimulation of the vagus nerve, which releases acetylcholine at the SA node of the heart. Acetylcholine acts on muscarinic receptors to decrease the heart rate (a process known as bradycardia), helping to lower the blood pressure back to normal levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Norepinephrine: Norepinephrine is typically released in response to a decrease in blood pressure, not an increase. It is a sympathetic neurotransmitter that increases heart rate and contractility, which would raise blood pressure, not lower it.

 

Option B. Epinephrine: Similar to norepinephrine, epinephrine is released by the adrenal medulla in response to stress or low blood pressure. It increases heart rate, myocardial contractility, and peripheral vasoconstriction, which elevates blood pressure. Therefore, it is not released in response to increased blood pressure.

 

Option C. Dopamine: Dopamine has various effects depending on the dose but is generally associated with increasing blood pressure and cardiac output. It is not involved in the reflex reduction of heart rate in response to high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetylcholine is released from the vagus nerve at the SA node in response to increased blood pressure, resulting in a decrease in heart rate (bradycardia) as part of the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text: Patient experiences softening of the cervix in early pregnancy. This sign is called as? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Goodell

 

Goodell's sign refers to the softening of the cervix, which is observed during early pregnancy. This sign occurs due to increased vascularization and changes in the connective tissue of the cervix, making it feel softer compared to the non-pregnant state, where the cervix feels firm like the tip of the nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osiander: This is incorrect. Osiander’s sign refers to the palpable pulsation of the uterine arteries felt through the lateral fornices during a vaginal examination in early pregnancy.

 

Option B. Chadwick: This is incorrect. Chadwick's sign, also known as Jacquemier’s sign, is the bluish discoloration of the vaginal mucosa and cervix due to increased blood flow during early pregnancy.

 

Option D. Hegar: This is incorrect. Hegar's sign involves the softening of the lower uterine segment, which is palpable during a bimanual examination, allowing the examiner's fingers to approximate between the uterus and the cervix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goodell's sign is the softening of the cervix, observed in early pregnancy due to increased vascularity, which makes the cervix feel soft, like the lips, compared to its usual firm texture

questions.text: A person fell in the dark while climbing stairs and sustained an injury to the posterior triangle of the neck from an iron nail. Afterwards, he experienced difficulty in raising his shoulder and was unable to shrug. Which structure is most likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Accessory nerve

 

The accessory nerve, also known as the 11th cranial nerve, innervates the trapezius muscle. The trapezius muscle is responsible for movements such as shrugging the shoulders. An injury to the posterior triangle of the neck could damage the accessory nerve, leading to weakness in the trapezius muscle. This would manifest as difficulty in raising the shoulder and an inability to shrug, as described in the scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is involved in the movement of the scapula, not shrugging of the shoulder. Damage to this nerve typically leads to a condition known as "winged scapula," not an inability to shrug.

 

Option B. Deltoid muscle: The deltoid muscle is responsible for the abduction of the arm, particularly the movement of the arm away from the body. While it plays a role in shoulder movement, it is not involved in shrugging the shoulder.

 

Option D. Sternocleidomastoid muscle: This muscle is involved in turning the chin to the opposite side and flexing the neck. It is not responsible for shoulder elevation or shrugging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accessory nerve is crucial for the function of the trapezius muscle, which enables the shrugging of the shoulder. An injury to this nerve can result in the inability to perform this action.

questions.text: MTP for failure of contraception can be done till: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20 weeks

 

The correct answer is 20 weeks. According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Amendment Act of 2021, termination of pregnancy for the failure of contraception can be performed up to 20 weeks. The Act outlines specific requirements for performing an MTP at different stages of pregnancy:

 

  1. Up to 20 weeks: MTP can be done for various reasons, including maternal health risks, fetal anomalies, pregnancy resulting from rape, or failure of contraception. Only one doctor's opinion is required for termination within this period.
  2. 20 to 24 weeks: Requires the opinion of two doctors. The reasons include threats to maternal health, fetal anomalies, pregnancy resulting from rape, pregnancies in minors, changes in marital status (e.g., becoming a widow or divorce), humanitarian grounds (e.g., war, natural disasters), or if the woman is disabled.
  3. Beyond 24 weeks: Termination is only permitted for substantial fetal malformations and requires approval from a medical board due to the viability of the fetus at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the MTP Amendment Act of 2021, MTP for failure of contraception can be performed up to 20 weeks with the opinion of one doctor.

choices.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman accompanied by her mother-in-law comes to the infertility clinic. She has been having regular intercourse for 6 months but is not able to conceive. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

 

Infertility is defined as the inability of a couple to conceive after 1 year of unprotected intercourse. For women under the age of 35, it is recommended to wait and try for one year before starting any investigations. Since the woman in this scenario is only 23 years old and has been trying to conceive for only 6 months, the best approach is to reassure her and advise her to continue trying. Investigations are not indicated at this stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semen analysis for husband: Although semen analysis is an essential part of infertility workup, it is typically not indicated until the couple has been trying to conceive for at least one year if the woman is under 35 years old.

 

Option C. Hysterolaparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure used to evaluate the female reproductive tract, typically reserved for cases where initial evaluations suggest abnormalities or for women who have been trying to conceive for a longer period.

 

Option D. Diagnostic hysteroscopy: This procedure is used to examine the inside of the uterus and is generally indicated for investigating suspected uterine abnormalities or after a longer period of unsuccessful conception attempts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women under 35 years old, it is recommended to try to conceive for one year before starting infertility investigations.

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is due to deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Laryngismus stridulus, also known as spasmodic croup, is characterized by sudden onset of apnea and a loud stridor due to respiratory obstruction caused by laryngospasm. This condition is often associated with rickets, which is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D. Rickets leads to softening and weakening of the bones in children, and it can also cause disturbances in the metabolism of calcium and phosphorus, leading to neuromuscular irritability, which in turn can result in laryngospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects the eyes, leading to conditions such as night blindness and xerophthalmia. It does not cause laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency is rare and typically presents with neurological symptoms due to its role as an antioxidant. It does not cause laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency leads to bleeding disorders because of its role in the synthesis of clotting factors. It is not associated with laryngismus stridulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngismus stridulus, characterized by sudden respiratory obstruction and stridor, is associated with rickets caused by Vitamin D deficiency. Recognizing the link between Vitamin D deficiency and laryngismus stridulus is important for diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: In the shown image, which one of the following is a source of vitamin B1? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Vitamin B1 (thiamine) is primarily found in whole grains, cereals, nuts, and legumes. The primary source of thiamine in grains is the aleurone layer, which is often removed during the polishing process of white rice. However, parboiling rice can help preserve this layer, retaining the vitamin B1 content. In the provided image, the food item labeled 'A' is rice, which is a source of vitamin B1, especially when not overly polished.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This option does not represent a significant source of vitamin B1. It appears to be a different food item that does not contain high levels of this vitamin.

 

Option C. The item labeled 'C' is not a grain or a food typically high in vitamin B1.

 

Option D. This option is also not a significant source of vitamin B1, as it does not represent a grain or similar food known for its thiamine content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B1 is primarily found in the aleurone layer of grains, which can be removed by polishing but is preserved in parboiled rice.

choices.text: A = pulmonary, B = aortic, C = tricuspid, D = mitral
A = aortic, B = pulmonary, C = tricuspid, D = mitral
A = tricuspid, B = aortic, C = pulmonary, D = mitral
A = aortic, B = tricuspid, C = pulmonary, D = mitral

questions.text: Correctly match the sites of cardiac valve auscultation from the given image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A = aortic, B = pulmonary, C = tricuspid, D = mitral

 

The sites for auscultation of the cardiac valves are specific locations on the chest where the sounds of the heart valves can best be heard. These locations do not correspond directly to the anatomical position of the valves but are determined by the direction in which the sound travels through the body. Here is the correct matching:

 

  • A. Aortic valve: Auscultation is best performed in the second intercostal space at the right sternal border.
  • B. Pulmonary valve: This is auscultated in the second intercostal space at the left sternal border.
  • C. Tricuspid valve: The best location for auscultation is at the fourth or fifth intercostal space at the left sternal border.
  • D. Mitral valve: The mitral valve is auscultated at the apex of the heart, which is located in the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The auscultation points for the heart valves are specific to each valve: Aortic (right second intercostal space), Pulmonary (left second intercostal space), Tricuspid (left fourth/fifth intercostal space), and Mitral (apex of the heart). Correct identification of these points is crucial for accurate cardiac examination.

questions.text: Identify the technique shown in the image: (FMGE JULY 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pringle technique

 

The image shows a surgical technique where the hepato-duodenal ligament is clamped. This procedure is known as the Pringle maneuver or Pringle technique. The Pringle maneuver is used to control intraoperative liver bleeding by clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein, thereby reducing blood flow to the liver. This maneuver is commonly used in cases of liver trauma or during liver resections to minimize blood loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cattel’s technique: This is incorrect because Cattel’s technique is used in IVC injury.

 

Option B. Mattox technique: Mattox technique is done in abnormal aortic injury.

 

Option D. Kocherization: This is incorrect because Kocherization refers to the mobilization of the duodenum to expose structures like the pancreas and is used in procedures such as the Whipple procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pringle maneuver involves clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein to control liver bleeding during surgery, by reducing the inflow of blood to the liver.

questions.text: A patient came to be emergency department with a radiograph showing posterior dislocation of hip. No associated fractures are seen. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed reduction

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF THE HIP

 

  • The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. 
  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed.
    • The occupant of the car is thrown forwards and his knee strikes against the dashboard. 
    • The axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction.
    • The force is transmitted up the femoral shaft, resulting in posterior dislocation of the hip. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

  • Clinical features: 
    • The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

  • Radiological features: 
    • The femoral head is out of the acetabulum. 

 

 

  • The thigh is internally rotated so that the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken.

 

  • Treatment:
    • In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. 
    • Closed reduction is the primary and most urgent step in the management of an acute traumatic hip dislocation without associated contraindications. 
    • The sooner the reduction, the lower the risk of complications like AVN. 
    • Open reduction may be required in cases where:
      • Closed reduction fails, usually in those presenting late
      • If there is intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction
      • If the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Such a fragment makes the hip unstable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open reduction. Open reduction is done when closed reduction fails, usually in patients presenting late OR if there is an intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction OR if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight bearing part of the acetabulum. Since the question states "No associated fractures are seen," and it's an acute presentation, open reduction is not the first line.

 

Option C. NCCT pelvis: A CT scan is very useful after closed reduction to check for concentric reduction, identify any occult fractures not seen on plain X-rays (especially small intra-articular fragments or acetabular wall fractures), and assess for incarceration of fragments. However, it is not the immediate next step before reduction in an uncomplicated dislocation, as delaying reduction to get a CT increases the risk of AVN. The priority is to reduce the hip.

 

Option D. Arthroplasty. Hip replacement surgery can be considered if optimal stability is not achieved with reduction and fixation of the associated injuries. It is a definitive surgical procedure, usually performed for severe arthritis or irreparable damage. It is definitely not the immediate next step for an acute hip dislocation in a patient who likely has no pre-existing severe joint disease and no associated fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following factor is involved in the extrinsic pathway? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VII

 

Factor VII participates in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

 

The prothrombin time (PT) assay is done to assesses the function of the proteins in the extrinsic pathway- Factors VII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B, C, & D. Factor VIII, IX, and XI participate in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation.

 

Factor VIII is a protein involved in the intrinsic pathway and its function is assessed by the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor VII is involved in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, and its function can be assessed by the prothrombin time (PT) assay.

questions.text: In Menke's disease, which of the following enzymes would be affected?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysyl oxidase

 

Lysyl oxidase is the enzyme affected in Menkes disease. Menkes disease is a genetic disorder that impairs copper absorption and transport, leading to a deficiency of copper-dependent enzymes like lysyl oxidase. Lysyl oxidase is crucial for the cross-linking of collagen and elastin fibers in connective tissues, and its deficiency results in connective tissue abnormalities seen in Menkes disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysyl hydroxylase: Lysyl hydroxylase is not directly affected by Menkes disease. Lysyl hydroxylase is involved in the post-translational modification of collagen, and its dysfunction can lead to certain types of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, not Menkes disease.

 

Option C. Prolyl oxidase: Prolyl oxidase is not directly associated with Menkes disease. It is involved in the formation of collagen cross-links but is not specifically affected in this condition.

 

Option D. Prolyl hydroxylase: Prolyl hydroxylase is not the enzyme affected by Menkes disease. It plays a role in collagen synthesis, but its deficiency is not a characteristic feature of Menkes disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menke’s kinky hair syndrome is an x-linked defect (affects only male child). It is a condition in which dietary copper is absorbed from GI tract; but cannot be transported to blood due to absence of an intracellular copper binding ATPase (mutation in ATP7A gene).

 

Copper is not mobilized from intestinal cells as well as in other tissue cells. The copper that has entered into the cell is not able to get out of the cells, and so it is accumulated. Hence, copper is not available for metabolism, resulting in defective cross-linking of connective tissue. Vascular and connective tissues are affected, and child dies usually in infancy. Deficiency of copper results in defective function of lysyl oxidase.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ER with the acute onset of ataxia. Neurological examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face on the left side and loss of pain and temperature sensation from the right half of the body. He also has dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lateral medullary syndrome

 

The patient's presentation with loss of pain and temperature sensation from the left side of the face and the right side of the body, along with dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex, suggests involvement of the lateral medulla. Additionally, the presence of Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) on the left side further supports this diagnosis.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). The key clinical features include:

 

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face due to involvement of the spinal trigeminal nucleus.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysarthria and dysphagia due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus (cranial nerves IX and X).
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome due to disruption of the descending sympathetic pathways.
  • Ataxia due to involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral pontine syndrome: Lateral pontine syndrome involves the pons and typically affects cranial nerves that are not involved in this patient's presentation. For example, it often involves the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), leading to facial weakness, which is not described in this case.

 

Option B. Medial medullary syndrome: Medial medullary syndrome affects the medial structures of the medulla, including the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII), and results in ipsilateral tongue weakness and contralateral hemiparesis. This does not match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Locked-In Syndrome: Locked-In Syndrome results from bilateral lesions in the ventral pons, leading to quadriplegia and anarthria, but with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements. The patient's symptoms do not align with this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is characterized by ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: Coral red fluorescence on Wood's lamp seen in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythrasma

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is erythrasma.

 

Erythrasma is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum and typically presents as hyperpigmented patches in skin folds, such as the axilla and toe web spaces. When examined under a Wood's lamp, which emits ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 365 nanometers, erythrasma exhibits a characteristic coral red fluorescence due to the porphyrins produced by the bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitiligo: Under a Wood's lamp, vitiligo shows a milky white fluorescence. This is due to the absence of melanin in the depigmented areas of the skin.

 

Option C. Pityriasis versicolor: Caused by the yeast Malassezia furfur, this condition shows a yellow fluorescence under a Wood's lamp.

 

Option D. Acanthosis nigricans: This condition does not exhibit any fluorescence under a Wood's lamp. It presents with hyperpigmentation and a velvety texture, particularly in skin folds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythrasma, caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum, presents with coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp, distinguishing it from other dermatological conditions that may exhibit different types of fluorescence or none at all.

questions.text: Declaration of Oslo is for? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Therapeutic abortion

 

The Declaration of Oslo was adopted by the World Medical Association (WMA) to address the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion. Therapeutic abortion refers to the termination of pregnancy performed to save the life of the pregnant woman, preserve her physical or mental health, or in cases of severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torture: The Declaration of Tokyo is the relevant document that deals with the ethical guidelines for doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment.

 

Option C. Hunger: The Declaration of Malta on Hunger Strikes provides ethical guidelines for physicians concerning the treatment of hunger strikers. This declaration emphasizes the importance of respecting the autonomy of individuals who engage in hunger strikes.

 

Option D. Ethical aspects of medical research: The Declaration of Helsinki is the key document that outlines ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects. It emphasizes the necessity of informed consent, the welfare of research participants, and the importance of conducting research with scientific integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Declaration of Oslo specifically addresses the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion, distinguishing it from other declarations that focus on different ethical issues in medical practice

questions.text: A patient presented with sudden, painful diminution of vision, difficulty in vision in light, and circumferential congestion with hypopyon as shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute Anterior Uveitis

 

Acute Anterior Uveitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the uveal tract of the eye, particularly the anterior segment. It is characterized by the sudden onset of pain, redness, photophobia (difficulty seeing in bright light), and diminished vision. A key finding in this condition is the presence of hypopyon, which is the accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, settling at the bottom.

 

Key clinical signs of Acute Anterior Uveitis includes:

 

1. Hypopyon - The accumulation of white cells (pus) in the anterior chamber.

 

 

2. Circumferential congestion (ciliary flush) - Redness around the corneal edge.

 

 

3. Miotic (small) pupil - A constricted pupil which is not typical in other conditions listed.

 

4. Posterior synechiae, which is an adhesion between the iris and the lens. When attempting to dilate a pupil with posterior synechiae, a festooned (flower-shaped) pupil may result.

 

5. On the corneal endothelium, keratic precipitates (KPs), which are cellular aggregates with protein deposits, are a pathognomonic feature of uveitis.

 

 

6. Painful, diminished vision - Common in inflammatory eye conditions like uveitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Congestive Glaucoma: This condition involves elevated intraocular pressure, severe eye pain, and blurred vision. However, the pupil in acute glaucoma is usually mid-dilated and sluggish, not miotic, and hypopyon is not a feature of glaucoma.

 

Option C. Acute Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis primarily affects the conjunctiva, causing redness, irritation, and discharge. Hypopyon is not seen in conjunctivitis, and the condition is not typically associated with severe pain or vision changes seen in uveitis.

 

Option D. Episcleritis: Episcleritis is an inflammation of the episclera, leading to redness and mild discomfort. It usually affects one quadrant and is rarely associated with hypopyon or significant visual symptoms. The pupil size remains normal, and there is no severe pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Anterior Uveitis is characterized by a painful red eye, circumcorneal congestion, hypopyon, and a miotic pupil, distinguishing it from other ocular conditions.

questions.text: Plethoric lung fields are seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. TAPVC

 

Explanation:

 

Plethoric lung fields are indicative of increased pulmonary arterial blood flow and are seen in:

 

  • Left to right shunts
  • TAPVC
  • TGA
  • Persistent truncus arteriosus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tricuspid atresia does not have plethoric lung fields because in this condition right atrium is atretic.

 

Option C. Ebstein’s anomaly has atrialisation of RV, leading to small outflow tract, and resultant reduced pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option D. TOF has oligemia due to infundibular pulmonary stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TAPVC is characterized by plethoric lung fields due to the excessive flow of oxygenated blood returning to the right side of the heart and flowing back into the lungs instead of going to the systemic circulation, leading to increased pulmonary pressure and congestion. This condition is a serious congenital heart defect that typically requires corrective surgery.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zika Virus

 

The image shows transplacental transmission of Zika virus given causing microcephaly.

 

Zika virus crosses the placental barrier and the developing blood–brain barrier (BBB). ZIKV exhibits clear tropism for proliferative neural cells, often with cytotoxic effects. ZIKV also productively and detrimentally infects cranial neural crest cells (CNCC), which give rise to cranial bones and can exert paracrine effects on the developing brain. Once Zika virions enter neurogenic regions in the brain, they reduce the number of mitotic progenitor cells by promoting cell cycle arrest and apoptotic cell death, autophagy, or possibly by precocious differentiation resulting in microcephaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus primarily causes encephalitis and respiratory illness but does not typically cause congenital infections or microcephaly.

 

Option C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV can cause congenital infections and microcephaly, but the image and description provided are specific to Zika virus.

 

Option D. Rubella: Rubella virus can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which includes microcephaly among other defects, but the specific viral transmission and pathology detailed in the image refer to Zika virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Zika virus is known for causing microcephaly through transplacental transmission by infecting and damaging neural progenitor cells in the developing fetal brain.

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A team of oncologists is implementing a new treatment strategy for metastatic melanoma that significantly improves overall survival rates for patients. How would you categorize the change in incidence and prevalence of metastatic melanoma in the population treated at this center? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a new treatment which can extend overall survival but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incidence increases and prevalence reduces: Incorrect as the new treatment does not affect the number of new cases.

 

Option B. Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same: Incorrect because the incidence is unaffected by treatment, and the prevalence would increase due to longer survival.

 

Option D. Incidence reduces and prevalence increases: Incorrect because the incidence remains the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Note - A treatment that extends the lives of patients with a chronic condition will increase prevalence, even if incidence remains stable.

questions.text: Observe the image below showing different food items. Identify the source of Thiamine. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) B (Rice)

 

Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism and the proper functioning of the nervous system. The primary dietary sources of thiamine are whole cereal grains, meat, and fish. In the context of the image provided, the food item labeled "B" corresponds to rice, which is a significant source of thiamine.

 

Rice, particularly unpolished or whole rice, contains a high level of thiamine in its outer layer. However, polished rice, commonly consumed in many parts of the world, loses much of its thiamine content due to the removal of the outer layer during polishing. This loss is a contributing factor to thiamine deficiency in populations that primarily consume polished rice, leading to conditions such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, especially among chronic alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Cucumber and onion: These items are not significant sources of thiamine. Vegetables like cucumbers and onions contain very low levels of thiamine and are not considered a primary dietary source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Chapati/Flatbread: Chapatis are made from wheat flour, which does contain some thiamine. However, it is not as significant a source as rice, particularly in the whole grain form.

 

Option D. Dal/Lentil Curry: While lentils do contain some thiamine, they are not considered a primary source compared to whole grains like rice. The thiamine content in legumes is present but not in quantities significant enough to be considered the best option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rice, especially in its whole or unpolished form, is a significant dietary source of thiamine (Vitamin B1).

 

Other sources – Whole cereal, meat, fish, legumes, ground nut.

choices.text: Datura – Abrin
Opium- Atropine
Nux vomica - Strychnine
Abrus precatorius – Thebaine

questions.text: Which of these is the correct match of plant poisons and their active principles: (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nux vomica- Strychnine

 

  • Nux vomica contains Strychnine and brucine as its active principles. Strychnine is a highly toxic alkaloid used as a pesticide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura – Abrin

 

  • Datura contains Atropine, Hyoscyamine, and Scopolamine. Abrin is the toxic principle of Abrus precatorius (rosary pea).

 

Option B. Opium - Atropine

 

  • Opium contains Morphine, Codeine, and Thebaine. Atropine is the active principle of Datura.

 

Option D. Abrus precatorius – Thebaine

 

  • Abrus precatorius contains Abrin. Thebaine is an alkaloid found in Opium.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: According to wound ballistics, A gunshot wound showing burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound, can be classified as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close shot entry wound

 

Burning (heat of the gases), blackening (deposition of soot) and tattooing (unburned powder particles embedding into the skin) are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds do not show burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are usually larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They show a clean entry hole.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Exit wounds from distant shots also do not show these features and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.
